caption:
Table 1: Comparison of MaPLe with different deep prompting designs in base-to-novel generalization. Results 
are averaged over 11 datasets. Co-CoOp ( Zhou et al. (2022a)) is the previous state-of-the-art. HM refers to 
harmonic mean.

Table 3: Comparison with state-of-the-art methods on base-to-novel generalization. MaPLe learns multi-
modal prompts and demonstrates strong generalization performance over existing methods on 11 different 
recognition datasets. Absolute gains over Co-CoOp are indicated in blue. 
(a) Average over 11 datasets 

Base Novel HM 

CLIP 
69.34 74.22 71.70 
CoOp 
82.69 63.22 71.66 
Co-CoOp 80.47 71.69 75.83 

MaPLe 
82.28 75.14 78.55 
+1.81 +3.45 +2.72 

(b) ImageNet.

caption:
Table 5. This indicates that utilizing multi-modal branch-aware prompting helps MaPLe 
in enhancing the generalization and robustness of V-L models like CLIP.

Table 5: Comparison of MaPLe with existing approaches in domain generalization setting. MaPLe shows 
highest performance on all target datasets.

Table 6: Ablation on prompt initialization. In general, the performance of MaPLe is affected by the choice of 
prompt initialization. Best results are achieved when only first layer prompts are initialized with the prompt 'a 
photo of a <category>'.
